The Grilled Philly Sandwich is pretty good. It's really big and very satisfying. The only thing that was a little off for me was the cheese was a little on the sweet side. 

Besides the sandwiches, they also have salads and Chinese food with a two item combo that would make you think you're at Panda Express, minus the heart burn. 

The Loving Hut is in the middle of the food court right by Bristol Farms and the entrance to Nordstrom. It's on the same level as the BART station too so it's really convenient. 

I'm looking forward to trying the tofu nuggets and some of the buffet items next time.
author: Daisy S.

description:
I think this place is vegan.
I recommend getting the garden vermicelli salad, which comes with noodles, lettuce, bean sprout, cucumber, herbs, fried rolls, and grilled soy protein. They give you some tasty dressing, and the water cups are HUGE! The water is in this big glass cooler.
You can also get a steamed table combo meal for $8.25 where you order either lo mein or fried rice PLUS two of several dishes, such as eggplant curry, lemongrass tofu, vegetables, sweet potato and chickpea curry, etc. The steamed combo meal has a lot of food on the plate by the way.
author: Jerry B.

description: All vegetarian and some gluten free options. A nice change from the standard mall fare. Queen sandwich is a nice size with a side salad. Filling but no so heavy you'd fall asleep at work or the movie upstairs.
author: Brian F.

description:
This rating is based on the tropical salad I just ordered. It is way too sweet. The papaya and carrots are fresh,but the dressing was to sweet. I was only able to eat a third of it.

Okay. I complained and they have me a plate of vegetable noodles. It is sweet too, but not as much.

Not coming back
author: Robert C.

description:
Loving Hut has been on my list for some time now & finally got to try it after a movie at Westfield

Verdict?  Grilled "Steak" sandwich was all that!

Soft French Roll, lots of flavorful "steak" w/ the best seasonings - tomatoes, lettuce & a side of Cole Slaw

But you're going to want to put that slaw *on* the sandwich 'cause that's almost the perfect pairing w/ a Grilled Steak sandwich!

The absolute best pairing & what would have put it over the top would have been cheese!  (vegan, of course)

This veggie says eating vegan doesn't mean you have to sacrifice flavor, as long as you're eating at Loving Hut!
author: Adrienne G.

description: I've been to the Supreme Master's other offerings and this one is the best. The salads are great and huge. Plenty of veggies. They also have brown rice which is a huge plus. Can't go wrong here, the rest of the foodcourt is just unhealthy stuff.
author: Lewis B.

description:
I needed a quick meal between appointments and Loving Hut in the Westfield mall food court was conveniently located. They are an all vegan restaurant, there was almost no line, and the service was prompt and friendly. A good spot for a vegetarian on the go. 

I'm not usually a fan of 'fake meat' but theirs is just strips of soy protein surrounded by whatever sauce/soup/sandwich/salad you've ordered. At least in the sweet potato curry and vegetable chow mien the soy is just fine.
author: Jaedra D.

description:
This place is not only good for a food court but is just an all around awesome place to eat if you are into not eating the meat. I would not disappointed if a boy took me here for a fancy dinner. That is how much I love this place. I am going to try everything on their menu hopefully. This is one of the great places I come to when I am once again in town. 

Looking forward to it already.
author: Cris F.

description:
I have been here too many times to count, and I love the "bar" of food that you pick 2 dishes and rice.  They have brown rice and they don't charge extra, and I always enjoy the vegan curry dishes they have.  

So grateful for this place existing in the mall - fantastic option if you find yourself starving and in the middle of shopping since its relatively healthy to fuel up here compared to, well, everything else I am aware of in the area that is also quick/fast dining.
author: Ali G.

description:
It's usually one of the more popular spots with a line, but it goes by quickly. I like the rice plate options. Half chow mien and half fried rice with 2 items. A lot of food for under $10! Everything always looks really good so it doesn't matter what you choose. Curry, lemon grass tofu, sweet and sour protein bites...The spicy noodle soup and pho is also good if you're looking for a soup option! I usually ask for all tofu and no mock meats. Don't forget to get a soymilk tea to go with your meal!

The best part of all is you don't feel guilty indulging in loving hut because it is all vegan. Best option in the mall food court for sure. If you're looking for a good quick bite this is it.
author: Stine H.

description:
TIP #1: Arguably the healthiest fare you will find in the Westfield food court! All menu options are vegan. 

TIP #2: Check out their display case--there might be a dessert or bun that isn't on the menu. 

Whether you've been shopping all day and need a quick healthy meal, or you work nearby and you're looking for a lunch that won't weight you down, be brave and wade through the crowds to get to Loving Hut! It's located across from the San Francisco Soup Company, which, incidentally, also serves soups and salads--but Loving Hut is a much better deal. 

I had the Rainbow Salad, which comes in a huge bowl. There are a plethora of veggies, all chopped into thin slices for easy, maximum crunch! The fake meat is cut into small strips and seasoned well so that they blend in rather than stand out. Sesame seeds added a toasty flavor and extra texture. All of that, plus the yummy peanut dressing, made for a scrumptious salad! My boyfriend's vermicelli with "beef" came with perfectly cooked noodles, fresh veggies, and egg rolls. 

Skip pricier, unhealthier food in favor of Loving Hut--your energy levels will be high and your gut will thank you!
author: A.L. H.

description:
Don't be fooled.  Not everything here is healthy.  Apparently too much soy can lead to early Alzheimer's and Seiten, which is like tofu fat, is not as innocent as it seems.  Maybe this is where Vegans can go and get their Trans-fats but if you want to eat light there are limited selections.  The curries especially are very caloric.  
That said, some of the dishes here are quite tasty.  I just hate when they are served luke-warm.
author: M S.

description:
Loving Hut, I just cannot love you! http://www.yelp.com/biz_photos/NoxxbgVp7ilvMm6O9FX9hA?select=QDo_8ds-fbF6T0hhWSem1w http://www.yelp.com/biz_photos/NoxxbgVp7ilvMm6O9FX9hA?select=2nryWC9NgfDYC3KIEhoKRw

I am not vegan but I eat vegan food since I am lactose intolerant and seafoodtarian. Vegan food is just easy for my tummy to digest, plus I love tofu.  I was excited by the presence of Loving Hut Vegan at the Bloomies Food Court.

1st Visit:  GRILLED PHILLY SANDWICH (0 Star)  $9.80 http://www.yelp.com/biz_photos/NoxxbgVp7ilvMm6O9FX9hA?select=3pkfAapW7NRvnnNUnCP2gw
(Soy protein, barbq sauce, vegan mayo, tomato, lettuce)

It has been months since I last ate barbecue beef and I admit I miss it. When I spotted the PHILLY SANDWICH, I was excited. I was not expecting it to taste like a beef Philly but I imagined a big piece of tofu steak in delicious barbecue sauce.  

First bite and I almost gagged. Awful! Terrible! Gross! The tofu filling for Loving Hut's Philly sandwich was slimy and had a really bizarre taste--not sweet, not spicy. It did not taste like barbecue sauce. My brain kept on saying "you are eating cat food"  and I had to ignore the voices.  After 3 bites, I took out the filling and ate the bun which was nice, crusty and warm, with the coleslaw which was actually pretty tasty. http://www.yelp.com/biz_photos/NoxxbgVp7ilvMm6O9FX9hA?select=Gwrrn_VFpIkHMNIl0dMBQg

I am not easily grossed out by the taste of food. Growing up in Manila I eat delicacies that are not for the faint of heart.  However, this was by far the grossest food I ever ate. 

2nd Visit:  2 ITEM LUNCH PLATE $9.03 http://www.yelp.com/biz_photos/NoxxbgVp7ilvMm6O9FX9hA?select=_4OgrtUM5BfIo6bk0JZy7w

As traumatized as I was with Philly Sandwich, I wanted to give Loving Hut another chance.

I thought a rice place couldn't be that bad.  I ordered with my brown rice:

SWEET AND SOUR SAVORY: Vegan version of Sweet and Sour Chicken. The flavorings were nice and spicy.  This dish was not bland and pretty good for a vegan dish. (3.5 Stars)

BEANS WITH VEGAN SHRIMP: If I leave the shrimp on the counter for 3 days then cook it, the consistency will probably be like the one at Loving Hut. Although it looked like real shrimp, it was slimy and not appetizing. The beans, though, were crunchy and nice. I did not eat the shrimp but finished my whole plate. (2.5 Stars)

Overall:
Do I expect vegan food to taste like the real meat? No.  
Have I had vegan food in the past? Many times and I love most of them. My ultimate favorite is the vegan duck that my friend used to make.

Some of the items at Loving Hut are actually tasty. Their meat substitutes are not only not good but not edible.

Why 1 Star? I know it's harsh. As much as the rice plate was okay, I just could not get over the awful Philly sandwich. If I give this sandwich to the homeless on Market Street, I  think they might say, "No, thanks. I might be hungry but not that hungry!"
author: Leah E.

description:
In town for work and found this spot. I saw good ratings and it was vegan/vegetarian. While I do eat meat, I thought I'd give it a try. Got the tropical salad, spring rolls and avocado smoothie. Avocado smoothie? Had to try it.

The salad was amazing!! I got it to go because I thought I'd only eat half of the spring rolls and salad, and wanted to take left overs back to the hotel...but I ate the whole salad. And I'd do it again!...probably tomorrow ;) Spring rolls were good too. As for the avocado smoothie? Hmmm, I can check it off my list. It wasn't bad, but it wasn't very good either. It was...interesting. :D

Loving hut, I love you!
author: Erica S.

description: I always love Loving Hut as it is a vegetarian place. Thank you so much. I am just sad that they took away the Vietnamese iced coffee on their menu. They still have the combo menus. I did not see also the veggie humbao for some reason. ;-( Otherwise, staff are still nice and helpful. Bartable. AT the food court.
author: Kitty D.

description:
As a fan of the Supreme Master restaurants, I'm even more stoked on this place, because it has more snack-y entree options, as opposed to just hot combo plates or noodle dishes.

For example, yesterday a friend and I got food to go. The two of us shared the chicken tenders with sweet potato fries, rainbow salad and the loving hut sandwich. All three of these entrees tasted super good, and the total cost was about $25.

It's awesome to see an all-vegan option in the mall, and especially one that has good food and average prices (and generous portions).
author: Natalye R.

description:
As a rabid fan of BBQ, steak houses, and all things meat I rarely go out of my way to find an all vegetarian restaurant. But in the spirit of being accommodating to my less protein inclined friends we checked out Loving Hut before going to a movie and were pleasantly surprised by what they had to offer.

The Pho is great. Though I thought it was funny how much effort is taken to make tofu look like meat. Give it up vegetable scientists.

The spring rolls were similarly tasty. All things should be covered in peanut sauce. Loving Hut is definitely worth checking out if you're in SoMa but be prepared to pay for your cruelty free lunch. Compassion ain't cheap.
author: Stephen C.

description: As someone who primarily cooks vegan, I hear about many vegan restaurants around the US.  When I was in San Francisco recently, I pulled out Yelp to get advice on grabbing a snack nearby.  I saw Loving Hut & thought "why not?"  I'm not sure how this location compares to others, as it was in a mall food court.  Therefore, the ambiance was not great.  Overall, the food was decent.  Think mall food court asian food.  The biggest plus is that the food was vegan, as it really wasn't all that special.  I had the eggplant & tofu with fried rice.  Okay for food court food, but wouldn't seek this place out for a real meal.
author: Jackie B.

description:
OK, albeit being a little bit pricey for food that sits out in a food court, I like the fact that it's healthy and tasty as well as easy on the calories when you need to make them count! Since I've started a very low carb and low calorie diet, I'm forced to watch what I eat, although it can be difficult to count calories when on the go during the day like I am. So I appreciate the fact that whenever I am craving Chinese food, this is the best option in the mall that offers brown rice and hearty portions. My favorite dishes (also the most flavorful) I would have to say are the Sweet and Sour-tofu, onions, bell peppers and pineapple in a sweet and sour sauce, minus the meat (their take on sweet and sour chicken) and it really tastes just as good, if not better than the meat version in my humble opinion! Besides this main dish I also get either the Kale, sauteed mushrooms or delicious eggplant as my second side. 

Bottom line: If you're forced to eat at the mall but you want to keep it healthy + organic or simply crave Chinese but want better quality for almost the same price as Panda Express definetely, then stop by the Loving Hut and you will NOT be disappointed!
author: Petra S.

description:
I eat here whenever my family is in this area - which isn't very often. But I like having a vegan/veggie option when everyone else can choose meat.

Today, I ordered the Veggie Pho - $8.99 - and I received a very full helping of tasty rice noodles, three different kinds of meat substitutes, and most of the usual toppings, including tons of alfalfa sprouts, basil and sliced jalapenos. I'm used to squeezing lemon into my pho, so when I asked for it, they gave that to me, too.

The pho broth was very flavorful - I'll admit, I didn't try it without the lemon squeeze I craved - and I liked that they gave three different kinds of meat substitute, which made the dish very colorful. I would definitely order this again.
author: Susan L.

description:
green tea milk tea, also made with soy creamer! Rockstar!

I'm totally cheating myself with this vegan creation
author: Joyce L.

description:
My memory of Loving Hut is this uber healthy, potentially too healthy for a foodie like me. But but but the basic mushroom at the Westfield mall Loving Hut, just straight from the counter, was sooooooo good. I ate a whole plate, yes, that's about 35 or more of them. 

The other item I love from Loving Hut, don't know if I can find it in this one, but surely at the Palo Alto Univ. avenue one is taro boba - real ground taro "juice", white milky and grainy, with tapioca. Really unique, and uber healthy (not the boba part, but hey, I will always eat boba)
author: Dilys S.

description:
What more could a vegan ask for in Union Sq? LOVING HUT.  I live near the Chinatown location and really like it too, but the prices at Westfield are much more reasonable.  The Combo Special is definitely where it's at.  They fill up your place so full, with two entrees and a side of rice or noodles for $9!!  In Chinatown, $9 doesn't even get you one entree (or at least not the one I really love - Orange Sesame Bites.)  And then there's the Queen sandwich - a banh mi sandwich truly meant for royalty.  

If I had more money, I'd probably eat here on my break from work every day. Well, maybe I wouldn't eat there (in the mall) but I would grab some hut and lose myself to its deliciousness.
author: Jon T.

description:
Normally I am pretty carnivorous...so Vegan fare is not very high on the hitlist.  This past weekend we did however have a huge fatty gourmet burger and chili cheese fries from TrueBurger for lunch.  As delicious as that was, we were definitely on meat overload and wanted something on the lighter side for dinner.  Since we were catching Tangled at Century in Westfield, we all decided to try Loving Hut in the food court.  My cousin and SO both ordered salads.  I went for the 2-item combo which included noodles & rice.  I picked the tofu entree and the potato curry.  My whole meal was honestly really delicious.  I had some of the Tropical Salad (essentially a green papaya salad) and it too was quite tasty.

For mall food, this place is a fresh alternative to some of the greasier food court options.
author: Justin L.

description:
Best place for vegan food in downtown ... i regularly go here for lunch ... wish they were nearer to montgomery : |..

Love their garden vermcelli .. its a noodle but has enough of salads and hell tastes so aweeeesome .. can't tell its vegan only !!
author: Deepak A.

description: Had the salad with seitan and was fairly impressed. I'm vegetarian so it resembled a chicken salad for me. Looking forward to trying the veggie Pho' next go'round.
author: Genghis S.

description: Delicious healthy affordable vegan cuisine in a FRIKKIN FOOD COURT?! Yes, please! Kale was green and perfectly cooked and salted -- lemongrass tofu was the perfect texture -- red curry vegetables were just the right spice.
author: Andrew K.

description:
Highlights: 
- Delicious Vegan Cuisine using organic items. Hot food items, salad, sandwiches, and noodle soups. They've got you covered. 
- Favorite is the 2 or even 1 item hot food that comes with fried rice or noodles. Mix and match, your choice. Love! 
- Their vegan meat is really good and texture tastes good. I also love their vegetable options, especially their kale. It's what's up! 

Improvements: 
- More locations and full on restaurants in the city please! 

Tip: 
If you have a chance to visit their full on restaurant, I would encourage you to do so for more yummy options to try! Every loving hut is unique and might have different menu items.
author: Tracy T.

description: Oh Loving Hut, I love you... Usually. In San Jose. Today we got to try you out on our staycation in SF. Awful customer service. Ordered the egg rolls and received hours-old cold rolls. Asked them if we could have fresh hot ones. They replied, we don't have a microwave. Whaaa? Had to beg and they finally made some fresh with a roll of the eyes. It took over 10 minutes, at least they came out hot. Yum yum, after beg beg.
author: Monellelarissa B.

description:
so, I'm walking out of Bloomie's ('cause I'm fancy like that), and.... wha?!?!?!!?  could it be?!?!?!?! is that a Supreme Master restaurant staring back at me?  I had no idea she was bringing her message of peace, love & environmentalism to malls.  whatevs. BRING ON THE VEGAN VITTLES!!!!!!!!

I am not ashamed to say (OK, leeetle bit ashamed to say), I found Loving Hut about 2 weeks ago & have already been back to this place twice... & I am looking for another excuse to go back to the mall.  

everything we had was the bom-diddi-bom di-dang di-dang diggi-diggi:
-lemongrass tofu (a tad spicy)
- chow mein
- fresh rolls (ask for extra sauce- YUM!!!)
- beef & broccoli (nom nom nom nom)
- green beans & shrimp (a tad spicy & those shrimp are kinda weird)
- Thai iced tea
author: Virginia D.

description:
Awful. 

Absolutly awful.

I managed BITES of their eggplant tofu (disgusting), their chow main (also disgusting) and I had one bite of the "beef" in the beef and broccoli and threw it away. That beef was the worst immitation beef I'd ever had. 

It was so awful, I didn't even give it to a person on the street. They'd have thrown it back at me. 

What an extreme disappointment.
author: Emily D.

description:
I've never eaten an actual Philly Cheesesteak so I can't tell you if the soy version that I housed last night was authentic or not, but it tasted pretty freaking legit to me.

I was traipsing around the Westfield Centre's food court after an unintended shopping spree at MaiDo Stationery (http://www.yelp.com/biz/maido-stationery-and-gifts-san-francisco - they just stocked their year-end planners and calendars so if you still organize your life on paper, run and check it out) like a zombie, not sure what I wanted to eat, and Loving Hut called my name. I settled on the Grilled Philly Sandwich ($8.95) which is an enormous amount of food.

A normal human would scarcely be able to finish a baguette piled high with marinated BBQ soy protein, veganaise, tomatoes and lettuce served with coleslaw and orange slices, but I was dealing with Hulk-sized hunger last night. Go here if you want a quality food court meal that's prepared with care!
author: Kat F.

description: I ordered spicy soup which was amazing, the basil mushrooms (also unreal), orange chicken (tasted like the real thing), my brother got a mock beef stir-fry & my fiancé had a noodle dish.  Everything was tasty
author: Corrie C.

description:
I dont know what it  is, but I love Loving hut. Their food is delicious IMO. 

This time around, they didnt have anymore spring rolls, which are my favorites to order, so I eventually went with the garden salad, that had eggrolls.  

Price is always higher with these places, but it was good and I was full afterwards. 

since it is in the shopping district of SF and the mall, it gets super busy and crowded.
author: Roger A.

description: Spicy Noodle Soup hits the spot! The people that were sitting in the adjacent table thought I was eating the "beef" pho - so meat eaters, shed your inhibitions and go vegan! You'll be glad you did - at Loving Hut! Mmmmmm.....
author: Sridhar R.

description:
This has become a go-to place for me when in the city and need a quick vegan bite. I've been to both the Westfield location as well as their Chinatown one. The mall location is in what may be the nicest food court I've seen. There are no Panda Express or Saborro's here.

The food had excellent flavor though it was a bit cooler than I'd like; with vegan food I guess that's less of an issue, but was still disappointing. Not enough to drop them from 5 stars though, which I feel they earn by having a good selection at good prices.

When I visited the Chinatown location I realized that this place has some sort of cult backing it. I wasn't preached at, but there was definitely some "grand master" stuff on the television and literature around. Again, it wasn't overbearing, but worth knowing when you go.
author: Damon T.

description:
This place is a lifesaver in an area not known for its vegan options. It's great if you're just grabbing a quick meal if you don't have much time, or you can sit down and enjoy the vegan goodness.

I usually just opt for the buffet, which usually means that I get brown rice, kale (because all vegans eat kale every single day, duh), and whatever else I'm feeling like. I've tried the sweet potato curry, sweet and sour something or other, green beans, and eggplant and tofu. All are decent, although sometimes the eggplant and tofu can be a little lacking in flavor.

Pro tips:
-You can get both brown rice and chow mein if you're so inclined.
-You can order a third buffet item for an extra $2. I do this more often than I'd like to admit.
-They also serve vegan desserts that are pretty decent.
-Despite it being a Loving Hut, there's no Supreme Master TV :(
author: Edward C.

description:
Delicious! And I'm not even close to a being a vegetarian/vegan.

Two sides and rice or noodles gets you the biggest plate of food for $8.50. Totally shareable for two.

Highly recommend this if you're contemplating a meal at Westfield.
author: Cat P.

description: I really enjoy the flavors here, but if I am paying $9 for a salad, I would expect a few more pieces of protein than the two tablespoons of tiny pieces of soy protein.
author: C C.

description: The bun (rice noodle bowl) here was excellent. Nice lemongrass flavor on the fake meat. Even better than the real thing...and yes I'm a bun connoisseur of America at least having sampled it all over the west coast and Texas.
author: Sanjay P.

description:
I love the rice vermicelli salad, heavenly salad, and the soups when I'm going to be sticking around.  A vegetarian diamond amidst the food court rough!

Yes, it's underground, somewhat dark, and in the middle of the mall, but it's a great choice when you're going with a bunch of coworkers, all of whom want different things.  Everyone is friendly, and the service is VERY fast.  You can either get rice/noodle, and pre-made combinations, or order from the menu.  Either way, you have your food in 3-5 minutes, and you're good to go.

The tea drinks are super good, but also very, very, sweet.  My current favorite is the green tea.
author: Jenni S.

description:
If you know me, you'll know that I love to eat meat. So for me to pass up on all the other options in the food court and eat here was tough for me. But since my friend Sara really wanted to eat here since she's vegetarian, I decided to eat here with her as well. 

I was truly surprised at how flavorful the food here was. Usually when I think of vegetarian food, I think of bland meals with not much flavor. I mean, c'mon, no meat. You've got to be kidding me. And then when you take that a step further and go to a Vegan restaurant, I was expecting the blandest food I've ever had. This could not be farther from the truth. The potato curry I had was extremely delicious. The lady tried to warn me that it was spicy but when I had it, it tasted super mild which shocked me considering how insistent she was that it was spicy. The Sweet and Sour Tofu was also really good although I really wish it was real pork instead of Tofu, hahaha. 

While I still rather go to a place where I can get meat, the food here was delicious enough where I would not be opposed to eat here again if any of my vegetarian/vegan friends are looking for a place to eat.
author: Gajan K.

description: Flavorful, reasonably priced, fresh, tasty vegan treats. You have to get the Vietnamese spring rolls with peanut sauce! Second to that...the garden vermicelli with marinated soy protein, fried rolls, and veg. It's the kind of lunch where you leave feeling really full, but in an awesome "I totally don't regret eating all that" kind of way. Fav quick lunch spot downtown!
author: Rachel A.

description:
11/01/2014
I rarely write restaurant reviews but after several visits to this Loving Hut fast food restaurant, both at Westfield Shopping Mall AND at the Sunset district in San Francisco, I must agree with other restaurant customers (see their comments below), and here's my general observation: 

-  Service:  extremely RUDE, HOSTILE, IMPOLITE manner from ALL the ladies at Westfield food court and at the restaurant.  What's wrong with you there, Ladies ??? I think you need to go back to elementary schools at least, or get some kind of degrees BEFORE applying for ANY jobs if you want to survive, especially in the U.S.
EDUCATION comes first, whether formal or informal.  It's the foundation of  your success in life.  

-  Food:  always SALTY.  Always COLD, even after their rewarming in microwave.  All "fake" meats  are made from frozen and processed food made in Taiwan, which you can find in most Asian grocery stores.

-  Price:  very OVERPRICED for such a LOW-QUALITY food.  Much more expensive than in many other Asian restaurants nearby, even with their formal and full staff service (with waiters, busboys, host/hostess serving you at the table).

-  Food SAFETY:  Watch out!  Some foods (especially the "Banh Bao" bun) is reheated in microwave with their UNremoved plastic wrap --- one of the causes for CANCER.  In fact, I did mention this to one of the serving ladies, but they chose to ignore it.  

Will I go back to this restaurant?  You bet I won't .  (I already tried and retried several times and give them a chance to improve themselves, but to NO avail.)

Now the choice is YOURS.  Good luck.
author: F. L.

description:
The best way to enjoy Loving Hut food is at a food court like Westfield where you are not subjected to the preachy tv channels like you are in their restaurants.

Vermicelli noodles all the way everyday!
author: Tina H.

description:
Great vermicelli vegan noodle salad.   The average median for mot to eat this per week is 2.6.

Spring rolls:  yes please
steak sandwich:  once was enough

I eat here a lot.
author: Mot Y.

description:
They have vegan options, which is great! 

Other than that, it's just an average food-court type place.  Nothing extraordinary.  Dessert was pre-packaged.  I ordered two veggies and brown rice and it was okay.  If you're starving and don't have many options, this place is an okay choice.  If you have other options-- take them.
author: Shea H.

description:
i love guys... great food!!
If you are vegan or not you better go there and try it.
the soup is fantastic!!!
author: B H.

description:
I wouldn't travel for this place or make it a destination by any means, but for vegan healthy-ish food in the middle of Union Square area, I think it does all right.

I appreciate the fact that they use organic tofu (GMO soy is GROSS), and that they have brown rice (also have white rice if you don't like brown rice). They also have lots of vegetables and their pre-made hot buffet food looks and tastes better and fresher than the average food court fare.

I have to agree with what others say though, what is with the mock meat? I hate mock meat! People are usually vegan or vegetarian because they don't want to eat meat, so why put fake stuff that looks like meat all over their food. It's not necessary, and you can just put organic tofu instead.

That being said it's pretty easy to avoid the mock meat or just ask them not to put it on their noodle salads and soups. I think their noodle soup was tasty and nourishing, but would have preferred more veggies and greens in it, and maybe even a soba noodle option for more whole grains and less refined white rice noodles.

If you have to eat at a food court, this place is a good option, and I"m happy it's around!
author: Carlin S.

description: You actually have to go into a shopping center to eat here but it was worth it. I had a delicious vegan sandwich and salad and my husband had several items from the buffet that were also delicious--kale, tofu and eggplant, and noodles. The noodles were my favorite--spicy and peanuty.
author: Hi T.

description: It's really fantastic to have a good vegetarian option in the mall foodcourt. I love the Queen sandwich, and not just because I'm a big ole queen.
author: Mark S.

description:
Finally I had a chance to try Loving Hut! It was hot hot hot on Tuesday and nothing like trekking to the mall for lunch where air conditioning is abundant. I ordered the garden vermicelli bowl and it was perfection. We're talking cool and crisp vermicelli noodles, sliced cucumbers, mint, lettuce, bean sprouts, faux beef that tasted very gingery, sliced carrot and topped with 2 fried spring rolls. This noodle bowl was delightfully tasty and refreshing, the accompanying sauce was light and delicate. Only issue was that a bowl and drink costs $12, which seems a bit steep. I'll be back!

Edit: Do not order the philly, it was atrocious. Very strange flavor, nothing like what a fake philly should taste like. Not BBQ'y at all.
author: Cori W.

description:
All of their dishes have so much oil in them, how can it be healthy? Service is terrible. The trays are piled so high that a guest in front of me spilled his drink on his plate of food and they didn't even offer him a new plate. The veggies are saturated in oil, how can it be healthy for you? Also, too much soy can mimic the effects of estrogen. 

I have this place a fair shot, but can't say I am going back.
author: Robin S.

description:
I'm a meat and potatos kind of girl.  Fried chicken.  Pulled pork.  Grilled steak.  You name it, I'll eat it.  But once a week or so, I crave vegetarian/vegan fare--my body never complains because it needs the detox.  Ananda Fuara and Golden Era are good sit-down meals, but Loving Hut is perfect for take-out.

I've been here twice and impressed twice, demonstrating that vegan food doesn't have to turn you off because it's completely devoid of delicious animal products.  I've had the Grilled Philly Sandwich and the Queen Sandwich, which taste similar and similarly yummy.  The soy protein was so flavorful and juicy--I liked that it was light and didn't mock meat.  My only complaint is that there's not enough of it for all the dense, fluffy bread.  I would've liked more soy protein for a $9 sandwich.

I enjoyed the milk tea beverages as well, but they were pricey at $3-4 or so.  Loving Hut is a welcome change from my meaty pace once in a while, but it's overpriced (what isn't in the Food Emporium, though?).  For $12-14, I'd just rather have three or four tofu sandwiches from Saigon Sandwiches.  Now that's fingerlickin' non-chicken.
author: Liz T.

description: I like eating at the Loving Hut restaurants, however, the food court version was not the same experience. I opted for the combo meal with brown rice and two entrees for $9 after tax. I chose eggplant with tofu and mixed veggies with tofu. The eggplant with tofu was good, but the other dish was okay. I can't imagine forgoing the rice to have a third item on the plate. Like what others said, the food was oil so you need to have rice or something to balance the oil.
author: Jackie S.

description: You can get 3 items from the steam table if you don't want rice/chow mein. I got spicy green beans, basil mushrooms and eggplant with tofu, all delish and vegan. Best option in the Westfield Food Emporium IMHO,  even if you're a omnivore like me. You get what you pay for so 9+ dollars for lunch is worth it to me.
author: B W.

description: Love this place!! Good service, very quick and very nice  wish I could come here more often. I'm not a vegetarian but this place makes me wana convert
author: Dominguez J.

description:
The tastiest Pho ever! The buffet is decent, but not crazy about the flavors. They have vegan cheese cake that I didn't get to try, but looking forward to it the next time I'm in the area. 

Great place to get a quick bite of healthy food.
author: Nicola W.

description: I really enjoy the food at Loving Hut. It's a bit zany down in the Westfield food court sometimes, but he staff is always calm and friendly. The food is very, very good. If you have nevr tried vegan food, this is a good place to start. I love their ph,
author: Mark F.

description:
While running around Union Square shopping at Louis Vutton, G-Star Raw, Chanel, and Old Navy - I stop and think, where would one get some delicious vegan food in the basement of a mall to recharge from all this awesome shopping?

Loving Hut, of course!

Sure, there are other food places in the food court that are vegetarian friendly, but nothing beats a truly vegan restaurant like Loving Hut.

Your best bet is to stick with the Asian dishes - I haven't had much luck with the sandwiches (I'll leave the vegetarian Philly Cheesesteaks to Jay's in the Mission). There's always rotating selections in the buffet combo (the eggplant dish is delish), some of which contain mock meat (I'd stay away from the ones that have faux seafood).

The best bang for your buck? The Garden Vermicelli noodle dish. It comes with two golden rolls and heaping amount of noodle, lettuce, bean sprout, cucumber, herbs and grilled soy protein. And don't forget to pour the sauce all over this heaping amount of stuff to make it come together.  I can't say I was a big fan of the Loving Hut Noodle Soup, so I'll stand by my Garden Vermicelli.

After being satisfied from the delicious nourishment, I wander upstairs and head to the Apple Store and wait in line for the latest and greatest iDevice...
author: Sean G.

description: We visited on St. Patrick's Day & were pleasantly surprised by the freshness & flavors of this mall-based location. We both ordered the $8.25-two items-plus-rice-or noodles plate. The portions (I had the curried sweet & sour vegetables with soy protein, basil tofu with eggplant, fried rice; my girlfriend had the curried sweet & sour vegetables with soy protein, lemongrass tofu, a combination of noodles & fried rice) were enough for both of us to have leftover meals, but the food was delicious enough we decided simply to scarf it all down. I realize the other, non-mall-based locations have more diverse menus, & we're both quite happy to know there's a location in Portland for our impending move.
author: Parker T.

description:
Oh, but I've missed this place.  It's like trendy vegan fast food, with prices to match, in a fancy food court that makes you feel ever so more upscale than if you were ordering a slice at Sbarro's with an Orange Julius (and I say that as someone who sheepishly likes both of those once in a great while).

Since I don't make it there often, I pretty much always get exactly the same thing, an order of spring rolls with peanut sauce, and a steamed bun, which is also delicious when dipped in the peanut sauce.  Even though those are both appetizers, together it's plenty of food for one person, so I rarely get a main meal.  

I'm docking one star because they're not very good about calling to you when your order is ready.  More than once I've had to walk back to the counter after watching for ten minutes, and have them tell me, "oh, it's right here" when the food has already begun to cool down.  I guess the alternative is to stand right there and not find yourself a seat first, but this happens even when I'm literally sitting at the table five feet away.  Be more loving, hut!
author: Joëlle M.

description:
I just had the most delicious, indulgent meal at Loving Hut and I'm sitting here in front of my computer writing this review because my food coma has rendered me incapable of doing anything more active.

This place is like the vegan version of Panda Express. I mean that in the best, most flattering way possible. This particular location offers a "buffet style combo" that gives you the exact same type of greasy guilty-pleasure chinese/asian food you would get at Panda, except the "vegan" part makes it seem more healthy, and the items they serve seem more authentic (thai curries, vietnamese vermicelli noodles, chinese eggplant stir-fry, etc.)

I ordered said buffet style combo ($8.25), thinking it was too much food and that I could get two meals out of it by saving the leftovers for another time. Silly me. I wolfed down that to-go box jam packed with fried rice, eggplant tofu stir-fry, and red vegetable curry in approximately 15 minutes. I then washed it down with their delicious vegan milk green tea (made with soy milk - hallelujah!).

I stumbled out of that food court a few pounds heavier, and very satisfied.
author: Amanda C.

description:
When I think of Loving Hut, I think of two things - delicious vegan "meat" and creepy television playing in the background.  I get that they're trying to push their beliefs, but seriously that television program they have on loop in all of their restaurants is awful mealtime accompaniment.  Anyway, this place is in a food court, so no creepy TVs.  The food is tasty, but be prepared to walk around a bit to look for a seat if you come during lunch hours.

Arbitrary power rankings:

Vegetarian: 10/10

Creepy propaganda: 0/10
author: Allen C.

description:
Definitely an excellent choice if you're in the mood for vegan food and want a tasty food court meal. Specifically the QUEEN SANDWICH is amazing, even if you aren't vegan - chewy faux meat, a sweet and savory sauce, cucumbers, etc. Sort of like a banh mi. Keep in mind everything is super oily/greasy, so it's not like this is a low calorie meal. 

Agreed that the service leaves much to be desired - I asked what the herbs were in the spring roll (as the menu just says 'herbs'), and saying it was an ordeal to get the answer is the understatement of the year. 3 different employees got involved, afterwards asking if i could just not have the herbs led to even more confusion/chaos. Ah well!
author: Kim C.

description:
It's nice to eat somewhere once in a while where you don't have to scan which products are vegan, and which aren't. Loving Hut is one of those places-- and I'm glad they're located in the mall where there are so many NON-vegan options (even at the smoothie joint next door).

$8.25+tax (about $9) will get you two items from the buffet-- mostly veganized Chinese food-- and brown or white rice. The brown rice is pretty tasty and the portions are just OK, not huge, not scant. Although, I can't say the food is particularly memorable. 

I also have had the steamed bun ($2, good for a snack, but lots of glutenous dough and not much bbq filling). It was also just OK, but I didn't like how they steamed it warm *inside* the plastic wrap so that it took me way too long to pull that gooey melted plastic off the bun. Minus one!

The carrot cupcake is also just OK. Kind of dry, crumbles apart when you try to eat it... I'd say at $3 it's a pass...
author: Debora L.

description: Just had their Oreo cake. And it was just what I needed, everything is vegan! Which is awesome and convenient in the mall
author: Monica C.

description:
Who knew their "pork" buns would end up being my favorite in the city? I'd take them over any of the pork buns on Clement. The reason is that they're actually savory, unlike the saccharine buns that dominate every other dim sum place in SF. Plus, these ones come with a generous filling.

Not as much of a fan of their cakes. The syrup used has a distinct flavor that just isn't to my liking.

Love the vermicelli. They've come up with a worthwhile alternative to fish sauce.
author: Aiko S.

description: Really good value if you don't get rice, because then you can sub for an additional dish! It's great if you love veggies, and I do. The eggplant is pretty good and I usually get the thai curry veggies. The kung pao thing is not good... do not get.
author: Sherry L.

description: Don't freak out too much about this vegan place you guys. It's just mediocre. I could have sworn the tofu was a bit sour, and it's obviously all deep fried (you can tell by the really bright green green beans and purple eggplant). So it's vegan but not really healthy. Take it as you will.
author: Sol L.

description: I'm amazed at the high rating this place has. Don't believe the hype. It's far from healthy, it's in a mall, and, well, 'nough said.
author: S P.

description:
This store represents the loving hut franchise well. Their food is very good and their menu allows for a measure of flexibility. For example, you can choose either rice or Chow Mein and a couple of additional items to go along with that (e.g., tofu curry, mushrooms). 

So, it's a little bit different then some of the fuller restaurant types of loving hut; but this store is very good, nevertheless.
author: Jamie R.

description:
I LOVE the fact that I can get a completely vegan meal while I'm in a shopping mall. 

The two item plate for $8.25 is a great deal. You get to pick a couple of entrees from the steam table, as well as a choice of rice or noodles.

I ordered the lemongrass tofu and the red curry vegetables with chow mein. They were a little skimpy with my noodles, so I had to knock this down to a 4-star review. However, the red curry had a wonderful sweet spiciness to it. I left satisfied, but still a bit hungry. 

Worth checking out if you're a vegan, or even if you're just curious about what vegan food is all about. Try it, you just might like it. :)
author: Brandi W.

description:
I LOVE their food. ALWAYS good. One of my favorite places to eat.

The servers are fast and pleasant. The thai iced tea is exceptional.
author: Casey M.

description: I was very impressed with the food here. It was a buffet style pick what you want in a food court & it was very tasty. The price was reasonable too. The thing that topped it all is the fact I was an idiot & left my wallet at the counter. The person at the register went & looked for me & gave it to me. How awesome is that. The other awesome thing is no one in line took it. Mind you this is in San Francisco! Thank you kind lady who works there. Our friends from out of town loved it too!
author: Leslie F.

description:
Only on the service and the thai ice tea. 
I was thirsty so I came here for a iced drink. My friend loves their thai ice teas so I thought I'll give it a try. No line at around 4pm. Came in the plastic cup cause it was to go. They didn't even fill it up to the top!!!! WHAT?! Service was fast though. I prefer the actual thai ice teas, not the vegan ones. A lot of ice!
author: Sarah C.

description:
UPDATE: I had the opportunity to try their Vietnamese style vermicelli bowl. It was actually pretty good and a great choice for those who want a lighter meal option while eating in the food court. 

Their stuffed dumplings or 'banh bao' was good too. 

Customer service is really fast and efficient.
author: Ann S.

description: I discovered their green milk tea with soy creamer today and decided I had to add this to my review. It's simply delicious!  I can't have dairy so I was so excited to see this on their menu.  They also have thai iced tea with soy creamer and iced french roast coffee with soy creamer. Now I know where to come if I'm ever craving a milk tea!
author: Angela F.

description:
I go to Loving Hut all the time, and this review is about their vegan "pork" buns. They've been out of them for months, and when I asked, they said they had stopped making them. 

Today I found they brought them back!! Seriously huge, tender, soft, yet chewy steamed buns of goodness. The "pork" is so close to the real thing that it will fool your non-vegan friends (I know because I used to eat meat).

It's yummy vegan fast food and always great service. Thank you, Loving Hut, for making such great food!
author: Holly G.

description:
When you specifically find yourself walking three blocks in the freezing cold for lunch at the mall, you know this is not your typically greasy food court grub! As a vegetarian, I have recently acquired a taste for veggie meat. While this is a fairly newfound love, eggplant has been my favorite food for a while. So, of course, I was in the mood for the eggplant for lunch. Lucky for me, after searching the empty Bristol Farms hot food bar, I saw the delicious Chinese eggplant at The Loving Hut. But, as soon as I had oohed and ahhed over the eggplant. My eye shifted to the tempting sweet and sour veggies and vegan meat. Finally, my eyes raced over to the steamed kale. The perfect lunch mix! 

While I usually run away like the Gingerbread man when I see the pre-made, terrible quality Asian food in a mall food court, the quality was far superior to the usual. While the Loving Hut is a chain, it seems that this location is slightly different presentation-wise as some of the actual restaurants don't offer the pre-made options. 

Taste. I first gobbled up the eggplant. It was a tiny bit overly mushy for my taste, but it still had a delicious salty, saucy flavor. It also came with perfectly chewy tofu. Fortunately, the brunt of the meal consisted of the eggplant. This led to a very busy and happy mouth. Next, I attacked the sweet and sour part of the meal. I absolutely love this sauce and would have liked a bit more sauce actually...The fake meat was a bit on the tougher side rather than one of the chewy brands. I clapped in delighted surprise when I tasted a piece of pineapple. I love cooked pineapple in Asian sauce--I could probably just eat an entire plate of this! There was a nice mix of veggies also. Finally the kale. Oh boy was it salty--but exactly what I was craving. I am a "kaleite." It is one of my favorite foods and this was steamed deliciously. It had a tiny bit too much sauce, but was scrumptious nonetheless. It is not that easy to find steamed kale at Asian restaurants. 

All in all, a few minor changes would have stepped the food up one more level. But, it was still a delicious and nutritious lunch. I would definitely return to try one of the many other tasty options that caught my eye. For a good deal (less than $10), try this unique vegan restaurant and you won't be disappointed.
author: Libby J.

description: I LOVE loving hut! I haven't had anything there that I didn't like (vermicelli bowl, tropical salad, pho, spicy noodle soup, spicy tofu veggies, green milk tea). This is my favorite spicy noodle soup I have found in the whole bay area and I literally walk 10 minutes every week (sometimes 2 - 3 times a week) to come and get it during my lunch break . Their fake meat is so good and so addicting. The pho is amazing too. Such good flavor! For being vegan, it is amazingly good. The service is also fast and the food is prepared very fast! The prices are reasonable, and the portions are very large. I HIGHLY recommend this loving hut!
author: Celia B.

description:
I always go to Vegetarian House in San Jose, which is owned by the same owner. So when I went to SF and decided to look around for some delicious vegetarian food, I am psyched when I saw Loving Hut! I knew that they had vegan vietnamese noodle soups, but since it wasn't in Vietnamese, I couldn't make out if it was pho or bun rieu (I feel like I have shamed my culture). In the end, I got the rice with two sides. I am seriously in love with eggplant tofu, so I had that and I also got this curry sweet potato dish.

The eggplant tofu was good! Nothing spectacular though. It has sesame seeds to top it off, so it was a nice touch. I do wish it had a BIT more flavor, but maybe I just have very bland taste buds. The sweet potato tofu curry was DELICIOUS... I debated whether to buy some to-go so I could bring it back to San Jose (which I didn't :[ ). The potatoes were so nicely cooked and the sweetness brought out the flavor of the whole dish. The dish also had small tofu cubes (which were delicious) and green/red bell peppers (I hate bell peppers so I can't say anything about that). 

My only complaint would probably be the service and the drinks. I stood in line for about a minute before being served (I was the only one in line!) and the lady that helped me did not seem happy to help me at all. Also, when I bought a drink, it wasn't even cold! All of them weren't cold, and I have no idea if they forgot to put the drinks in ice or not. 

But the food was fantastic. I will definitely go back (when I go back to the wonderful city of San Francisco!)
author: Jennifer L.

description: I've eaten at this location several times and the food is really good. The Queen Sandwich is the best Banh sandwich I've ever had. The textured protein is slightly sweet, juicy and taste just like pork. It is absolutely delicious.
author: Tayo O.

description: Loved the food here. The portions are great as is the price. The vermicelli bowl was delicious, tofu spring rice rolls were amazing and the nuggets with sweet potato fries were awesome! Worth trying.
author: Aya O.

description: Super pleased to find such a great variety of vegan options and the Garden vermicelli was delicious and the price very reasonable. Yum, yum, yum.
author: Bonnie W.

description:
In search of a quick, cheap, healthy dinner nearby in Union Square, I found Loving Hut, which was located in the food court in the Westfield mall. 

I've heard of Loving Hut before (there is one back in Los Angeles in Alhambra) and always wanted to try it. It was surprisingly good! I'm starting to like vegan food more and more these days. For the price, the portion was not bad either. I left with a full box of food for only $9. Good deal.

It was peak dinnertime around 7PM when I went, but the line moved fast. I ordered the combo meal, which came with two sides and brown rice from the steam table. I picked eggplant stir-fry and spicy tofu curry with potatos and carrots as my sides. Those two items looked the best. Fortunately, both were as tasty as they looked and the spicy curry had a good kick to it. I would eat here again for sure.

4 stars for a delicious, vegetarian meal at under $10.
author: Cynthia L.

description:
Yesterday, I ordered a sandwich and a smoothie. I got a cold, disinterested vibe from the worker who took my order. I paid at the counter, which was jam-packed with stacks of trays as if the staff wanted to hide behind a wall, not considering the needs of customers to set something down for a moment. Then I was given an order pager.

The pager activated, and I get to the counter and see my sandwich but not the smoothie. I asked about the drink, and the person handing me my food had no idea what I meant. She checked the order ticket, then rudely told me to go eat and wait to be paged again. So I was faced with being separated from some combination of my food, backpack, and jacket while navigating a crowded seating area because the staff didn't care enough to deliver my items together.

The food was fine but the service was appalling.
author: Brett N.

description: I try it for the first time.. i don't like it.. i'm a meat guy.. i'm sure it's good if you don't like meat . :)
author: Daniel W.

description: Got the garden noodle bowl here, it's vermicelli and veggies plus fried seitan egg rolls. It was good but not as good as I expected given my experience with the loving hut in L.A. But I guess that's what you get for mall food court food.
author: Rowena L.

description: My family member and I had the Garden Vermicelli and Tropical Salad.  Although very tasty at the time, we both ended up getting some unpleasant indigestion afterwards.  We're both sure the salad was the culprit.  I'm hoping it's a fluke and would like to recommend this place, but I more than likely won't dine here again.
author: Kiet N.

description:
Loving Hut. It has so many good ratings, but I just don't feel the greatness of this place. Maybe it's because this location has a tiny menu compared to the others. This place is like the size of a small kiosk.

== Food ==

Buffet items were pretty good. They let you do a half and half on the rice and noodles. The best of both worlds. The buffet items are pretty fresh and they're pretty okay. 

Vermicelli noodles with grilled "meat". I'm pretty amazed that someone can make fake meat look so real, but the texture is completely wrong. It feels like chewing on a sponge. The fake meat thing just throws me off. Why are you trying to be vegan and have fake meat. Well, the other things inside the dish were pretty good. Noodles and veggies were fresh.

== Overall ==

This place is kind of pricy for so so food. Is it the mall food effect? The other locations have an amazing menu, but this being a small kiosk like restaurant has a small menu.
author: Steven B.

description:
Chong is vegetarian and I, Cheech am a hardcore carnivore so you can imagine what eating together is like---  a f&&&ing nightmare, yeaah. 

Before hitting up Yoppis we agreed real food was in order. Real food is a stretch because their plates were questionable. 

This vegan place was strange to me, the food looks strangely unreal, an unusual way to describe tofu meat that looked just like beef vermicelli. 

The service sucks no question, I imagine any place in the food court has 2 star service. Rightfully so, because it def sucks to work there, I speak from experience!

The portions are generous and it's not entirely pricey considering what I have paid for in the past for "vegan cuisine" 

Chong and I shared a side of sauteed mushrooms in a black bean sauce, lemon grass tofu and half rice and half chowmein completed with a Thai ice tea. 

The taste was bland, average, nothing special, really light, makes you want a steak so bad....you know, that kind. It definitely wasn't one of the few vegetarian places that suffice for a real meal. But I could tell the quality was there, I felt a big change in energy when I was finished with my plate. 

Chongs review of this place would be complete opposite of mine. hahahaha
author: Olivia Vanessa R.

description: This place is great but on the oily side. Would come here all the time if it was closer :) very filling for what you pay for. How lucky is it to be able to eat vegan fried rice and chow mein?
author: Dorothy T.

description: Delicious. Plenty of menu items. Had a combo chow mein with 2 items, kale and a sweet and sour protein dish. Also had a tropical salad (papaya) a bit sweet but very good.
author: Steve C.

description:
Chinese Mall Food is Chinese Mall Food is Chinese Mall Food.  So the meat is not real, but then again I've often questioned the meat authenticity of mall food court joints that don't claim to be vegan anyways.  As a true omnivore I am not biased by the lack of vegan places which could cause some to inflate a food rating when a new one opens.  Instead, I judge on food alone and can say I was not impressed.

Beef & Broccoli: Only a few flecks of "beef" amongst firm and barely steamed huge stalks of broccoli.  I'm all about veganizing meat dishes, but why choose a mediocre Americanized (in a bad way) Chinese fast food dish?  The "beef" did feel and taste like the real bovine deal so they accomplished that feat, though they should have added more of it.

String Beans & Shrimp: ONE "shrimp" amongst some crisp string beans.  Seriously?  Isn't soy product cheaper than shellfish?!?!?  It was a tasty shrimp with a texture similar to fish cake rather than actual stringy shrimp.  The string beans were in a nice spicy sauce.  Though I was a bit too salty that they only gave me one stinking shrimp to enjoy this!

Lo Mein: The highest ranking of the dishes I tried, but that is a low bar.  The "pork" was spot on and the noodles were filling.  Just enough veggies to add a fresh crisp and texture without overpowering the starchy carbs.  As good as any fast food mall pork lo mein I've had without the animal slaughter.

Chicken Nuggets: No better than those frozen vegan chik'n nuggets at Safeway.  In fact, might have been the same ones!  Real chicken nuggets don't taste much like chicken so this was a good facsimile, but I expected more innovation from a restaurant like this.

Sweet Potato Fries: Standard, common, boring.  Seems like everyone does sweet potato fries nowadays.  Just like any other.
author: Adam B.

description: THE QUEEN SANDWICH! ask for extra protein! I am NOT vegan and it is absolutely delicious! Also the spring rolls are amazingly fresh!
author: Alyssa P.

description:
Mmmm....Tasty vegan food in the mall. 

The sandwiches are great and huge (a full on meal, maybe even 2 meals). Haven't had much else, but I'm sure I'll try the Vermicelli soon!

I have heard that this place is a lot more expensive than their actual location in the sunset, but I guess that makes sense, you pay for convenience.
author: Helen D.

description:
Wonderful! It is difficult to find delicious vegan healthy food in a mall! 

I ordered the special and the vermicelli salad. The two dish special was flavorful~I really enjoyed the sweet potato curry! The vermicelli salad was filled with cilantro and other herbs. I really liked how crispy the egg roll and was filled with vegetables. 
I felt that the green beans were hit or miss because when I first tried the green beans they were undercooked. 

Overall, I felt that Loving Hut is a wonderful delicious food for a good price! 
I hope to try some of their desserts next time that I visit. Also I want to try the kale.
author: Sara N.

description: Insanely delicious! The sweet and sour stir fry is unbelievable. Zero complaints!
author: JD D.

description: Had the veggie Philly which was just meh at best.  The thai tea was good but way over priced. Oh, and they were out of the side dish so they just said sorry instead of offering me something else or discounting the meal.
author: Kory-Oren E.

description: The vegan "pho" is delicious. A little oily but still delicious.  I don't even know what was in it other than bean sprouts, jalapenos and tofu but the flavors were awesome and it was a huge bowl for $9.  When I was finished, it didn't even look like I had made a dent in the bowl.
author: Amanda K.

description:
The people who work at this Loving Hut are always so happy and smiling! It's almost infectious...

No animal products or by-products, so vegans rejoice for there is a completely vegan place to eat at the mall!

This little Loving Hut is very much like a vegan version of Panda Express. You can get the 2-item combo special... Or there are a few sandwiches, soups, and special main plates to choose from. There's even a vegan fried tenders and french fries dish, for those who are looking for classic American kid-friendly fried food.

I liked being able to stop by this spot to grab a steamed bun or four, because those bad boys taste so much like the non-vegan steamed pork buns.

Overall, it's a great place to stop in the mall for those vegans worrying they won't find anything to eat in the middle of food court madness...
author: Miss C.

description: Good food. Service is terrible. And they have bad attitudes. You shouldn't have to ask for a glass of water 3 times.
author: Rusty C.

description: Delicious cruelty-free food, reasonable prices, huge portions, and friendly staff! What's not to like?
author: Danielle S.

description: I ended up the last person to get whatever veggies were available. On the eve of nye... The food was awesome.
author: Rainth K.

description: This place has great vegan meals. I love the vegan pork bun and the spring rolls are my favorite.
author: Misty P.

description: Great vegan food.  I can't help myself every time I am downtown I have to go eat there.  The best restaurant at the Westfield Mall.
author: Nadia M.

description: Congrats to this place on my quest for the last 6 years to find the best vermicelli bowl. Genius. Pure Vegan. Awesome.
author: Dominic S.

description: The 2 item plate deal is fantastic for a delicious and fulfilling meal! The eggplant with tofu and the sweet potato curry are definitely good choices! The kale smoothie was refreshing..had a slight ginger kick to it but it's not too noticeable.
author: Cheri C.

description:
From so many choices Westfield has to offer in this food court I love coming here. 
It's Vegan so that's a plus for me. 
Also the buffet for like four items is good for like eight dollars. 
The eggplant is very good as well as the potato yellow curry; and i always get half rice and half noodles. I'm content with their serving size(if feel heavy when i get a to go box). 
If it's not Chipotle I come here if I'm near by shopping around.
author: Nadav M.

description: I would give this place 6 stars for the Loving Hut Sandwich if I could. Despite being a chain restaurant, it serves the best damn vegetarian sandwich. I can't get enough of its soy protein and have to get it whenever I'm in SF.
author: A J.

description: the only fully vegan place in the mall and it's so good! I go about 3 times a week. I'm vegan and its the closest thing to my job. I have never had anything i didn't enjoy.  and the staff is always very friendly.
author: Rachel E.

description: Pesto chicken sandwich FTW!  Crunchy toasted baguette with savory seasoned grilled veg chicken, tomatoes and greens.  Pair with seasoned kale and button mushrooms!  So delicious!
author: Coy T.

description:
I'm not a big fan of malls in general, but I always find myself in the Centre when my mom is in town.  I was a slave to Out the Door whenever I hit their food court, but ever since Loving Hut opened, I haven't given any of the other restaurants there a chance.

I usually opt for the combo meal (rice + two sides from their steam table), but I've also had the garden vermicelli and their steamed buns; I have yet to be disappointed.  I haven't tried their sandwiches (and fries, the American part of their predominantly Asian menu), but they do sound delicious.  You'll be spending about $10 for a meal, but the portions are generous.  Though there's no table service, I've found the staff/cashier to be cheery and friendly. 

I loved the food at their sit-down restaurant in Chinatown as well, which has a more extensive menu, but I found their service to be lacking, and I haven't been back to that location in at least a year.  They seem to do better in a grab-and-go type setting, which makes this food court Loving Hut the optimal dining choice for vegetarians/vegans.
author: Marsha Z.

description:
Vegan galorrrreee!!! 

This place is like a Chinese restaurant, only it's VEGAN! & oh so tasty!!!  I gave up meat for about 9 months last year and when I went to sf I saw this place on yelp. It was actually my first vegan restaurant and really really really love it! :) every dish I had was full of flavor!  I don't quite remember exact names but I had about 5 dishes a la carte and I don't remember any complaints about them! This is a must try place!!! AND the prices for each dish run about $7 $8 dollars. Very affordable! They also have vegan desserts!!! Which is another reason for me to go back and try em out!
author: Katherine b.

description:
Check out their lunch buffet; you get to choose three entrees and you receive a generous scoop of each.  All for only $6!  

I'm so glad there is a vegan option like Loving Hut in the Westfield food court.  Very convenient for my lunch break at work.  I've introduced my co-workers to this place, and even the omnivores had to admit that the faux meat was delicious.  

Loving Hut sells vegan cake, so you can buy your vegan co-worker a birthday cake or cupcake :)
author: Jennifer B.

description:
A decent veg option in the Bloomingdale's mall food court.

I had the noodle salad, the dressing was tasty and healthy, they had mint in the greens that made it really good. They had bits of some vegetarian-fake-meat that didn't do much.

Over all - in a pinch I would do it again.For me the best option in that food court.
author: Hari B.

description: I was here last month and needed a healthy option for lunch. I got the Garden Vermicelli. It was yummy and satisfying, I forgot I was eating vegan. I would come here again if ever in SF.
author: Monica B.

description: The sweet and sour and stir fried rice are my favorites. I'd give this 5 stars but the spicy tofu and vegetables was just OK.
author: Martha H.

description:
I am not a vegan or a vegetarian, I just thought I would order a healthier lunch for a change. 

I ordered the 2 dish with rice lunch. I got the eggplant, the tofu sweet and sour thingy and fried rice. (I didn't see that steamed was an option but I didn't ask either) 

The flavors were good on both dishes. The eggplant could have been cut into smaller pieces in my opinion. 

If I were a vegetarian, I would return. Ultimately it did not seem healthier than any other Chinese place, I may be wrong. It was also a little more expensive than most places.
author: Amanda L.

description:
cool alternative in the food court when you just dont wanna eat meat for lunch- 
I am always here in between work and school days to get either spring rolls or vegan nuggets. I would also recommend the green tea milk (isn't green, but yummy nonetheless) if you want to treat yourself to a little something extra. This place makes it easy for the vegan/vegetarian hesitant !
author: Bubba C.

description: I think it's great that there is a all vegan restaurant in a mall food court. At this Loving Hut location there are some solid options: I went for the noodles and a pile of the mushrooms. The portions were huge (which was awesome), and the service fast. My only complaint is the lack of hot sauce.
author: Tommy T.

description:
Vegan mall food!

Thank you Loving Hut!  If you're vegan and haven't hear of this chain, you're missing out.  I've been to locations all over Cali and Hawaii and it's great comfort to know that consistently good vegan/pan-asian food is nearby!

My fave dish is the LemonGrass tofu.  Also, this location often has the carrot cake cupcakes... excellent.

I will say that this location's food isn't quite as good as some of the others, but the others aren't buffet style either so the food is fresher.
author: Christopher R.

description:
I must admit I am a fan of this chain. Had the lunch special - two items and noodles or rice.  Had the noodles - not bad.  For my two items  the chicken sweet sour was great.  Mongolian 'beef' was the second item - good.  Texture was great. 

anyone looking for vegan, this is a place to try.  Next time, will have to order off the menu.
author: Bill L.

description: This location doesn't have as many options as the other Loving Huts, but it gets the job done. This is the place for getting a 2 entree combo with some rice or chow mein. Don't forget your vegan Thai tea!
author: Natalie C.

description: Stumbled into this little gem. Loving hut sandwich and the pho noodles kept me coming back everyday over my week visit to San Francisco.
author: Michael J.

description: Five people had gotten their food and paid before they remembered about my single order of spring rolls. I'm not coming here again.
author: Maggie L.

description:
I've tried to love Loving Hut, and I've tried hard to like Loving Hut, but it doesn't work.  I can't get into the menu, the food is inconsistent and often cooked badly.  

Most recently, I got a noodle soup with noodles so overcooked that the noodles just kind of dissolved.  It was supposed to be spicy, but the hot oil was just poured and pooled on top of the broth, which was almost sweet.  Previously, I have bubble tea (okay), a sandwich (again, savory food that was too sweet), and a salad that pissed off my stomach for hours.

If you're in a real pinch, it won't kill you, but it always makes me question why I didn't just buy a burger.
author: Laureli K.

description: Really thought this was going to be a glorified albeit vegan, Panda Express. Boy, was I pleasantly surprised! Went with the husband who is very skeptical of any vegan establishment (super carnivore)! Not only did we both thoroughly enjoy what we ordered (get the mushrooms!) but we were full to the brim. So good!
author: Emma C.

description:
I am a fan of the spicy noodle soup! I've also tried their tofu eggplant and sweet and sour savor dishes and enjoyed them all. Never thought I'd be a fan of fake meat after having tried veggie hot dogs and bacon. Ew.

A tad pricier than your average mall food, but I'm willing to pay a few dollars more for this than grab something at Panda Express. I'll be back for more!
author: Zell C.

description:
spring rolls are always yummy, i was shocked at the size of the peanut sauce that came with it but how DID I EAT ALL OF IT?

the pork steamed bun was super disappointing, it was 90% dough and lacking flavor. go to Good Karma Vegan House in San Jose for the BEST bun ever.
author: Ellie B.

description:
Yay!  Only in SF can you find a vegan restaurant in a food court at the mall! 

After a full day of walking and attending a convention, it was great to see a vegan restaurant so close to the Moscone Center. 

My boyfriend and I had the vermicelli bowl and a 2-entree plate. Between the two, I liked the vermicelli bowl better. I chose the 2-entree place because it is so hard to find vegan chow mein! 

Their service was fast and friendly. No complaints there!
author: Linh N.

description: I love this place! Not as many options as their normal restaurant, but definitely enough choices for a food court. I recently got their bowl of pho soup - delicious! And they give you a really big portion for the price, which I appreciate. I actually had to take some home because there was so much! Also ordered their spring rolls, which I devoured. My friend & I split their pumpkin cheese cake, which we both immediately regretted not ordering our own. It was so so good!
author: Jessica K.

description:
like yelp's 2 stars review say, "Meh. I've experienced better" 

i usually love loving hut but this location wasn't very good.  for some odd reason, i was craving the golden nuggets one day.  it wasn't on their menu so i asked if they had it, the girl nodded yes.. and i asked AGAIN to make sure she wasn't confusing it with some other crap, so i said something along the lines of "the thing that looks like chicken nuggets..but not?" and she said, "yea, we have it!"

my order came out. and it was golden egg rolls. didn't enjoy it very much. partly because i was expecting and craving golden nuggets and the other part is that i'm not a huge fan of eggrolls, especially vegetarian eggrolls. 

their green milk tea is pretty good though. a little too much ice for the amount of tea, but i would get it again. (and ask for less ice..)
author: Irene U.

description:
I work about a half mile from this place and I occasionally come here for lunch, usually on foot but sometimes on one of the Muni metro lines. They have a small regular menu, including a few sandwiches, but the easiest thing to do is to order the two item buffet special. You pick two items and rice or noodles -- I always get the brown rice. It's like Panda Express, but vegan and delicious.

It's easy to fall into a rut and start ordering the same items every time, but I try to mix it up. I haven't been disappointed in any of the food so far.
author: Ed G.

description:
As a vegger (lacto-vegetarian for now, that is), I'm so grateful for SF when I can find a vegan place in a food court! I work near here, so my typically twice-weekly trips to Loving Hut are not a blessing for my lunch budget, but it's so good and easy I just can't help myself.

I usually get the combo for which, after tax, you part with $9.03 and receive either white rice, brown rice, fried rice, or chow mein with two selections from approximately 10 dishes available. I like that you can see what you're choosing from, I like that they'll give you more or less food if you ask for it, I like that I can see them frequently replacing the dishes so even though it's in the window I know it is actually hot and fresh. I recommend the basil mushroom and sweet potato curry. Watch out if you have a low spice tolerance- some of the other dishes might be too much for you!

Consistent, quality ingredients, I like their purpose/message, the food fills me up and makes me happy :) What more could a girl ask for?

Well there WERE those shoes upstairs...
author: Ashley L.

description: The Pad Thai with shrimp I ordered here was great! Although the shrimp was made from tofu, it looked just like shrimp and was great! The Pad Thai noodles were excellent too.  For dessert, I had the tofu Cheesecake and that was great too!  This place is great if you want a plant based meal--no meat, no eggs, no milk, no cheese, no kidding!  The waiter Vinh was very friendly and knowledgeable about the benefits of a vegan diet.  The place was very clean and there is a complimentary DVD at the front entrance that helps educated the importance of a total vegan diet--it is better for our health and helps to save our planet.
author: Robert T.

description: This is my go-to place in the food court when I'm keeping it vegetarian.  I always order from the Panda Express mode pre-cooked food so I can't comment on the sandwiches or salads.  I've had several different items and everything tasted good and fresh and healthy.  The kale juice is especially outstanding but a splurge ($4.50).
author: Neill T.

description: Their QUEEN SANDWICH is the bomb dot com! A bit pricey though... but what isn't in d food court anyway?
author: Jays D.

description: Had their Pho which was a-ok. Service was good though. I would go back again so I can try something different.
author: Yuto S.

description: We had sandwiches - grilled philly and the loving hut. Very tasty. Though the coleslaw tasted foul. Seemed a little over priced. Not bad if you're in a pinch.
author: Graham T.

description: The food has a lot of flavor! I got the 2 sides with noddles. So good...the curry has a nice spice to it and the noodles are thin but flavorful. I would come back.
author: Sahira B.

description: I love eating at this Loving Hut location! It's easily accessible, and the atmosphere in the mall is always fun and exciting. I ADORE being able to go into a mall and find VEGAN FOOD. It's so mind boggling to me, and it's always very exciting. The food here is fast, insanely delicious and pretty cheap. I am never disappointed by the Philly sandwich, which is my staple here. I wish they had a few more menu options, but eh. Definitely worth a visit!
author: Callie O.

description:
I'm the kind of person that hear's "vegetarian food" and thinks "blech! more bland tasteless food".  Well, one of my vegetarian friends told me to go try Loving Hut. I was reluctant to do it but finally one time I was in the Westfield Mall and thought, what the heck.

YUM! Of all vegetarian food was this good I'd have no problem being a vegetarian most of the time. I'd still crave some meat once in a while but Loving Hut was great.

Not the question is, WTF are all the other vegetarian places so crap.
author: Gregg T.

description: This fast food version is not as good as the actual restaurant. But it's not too bad for a quick bite.
author: Jimish S.

description: When you think vegan, you think no meat, you think no meat you might think less flavor - which was unfortunately the case with my spring rolls. The do not add mint to their spring rolls, leaving you with tasteless noodles, lettuce, and a chewy rice wrapper. There is a small sprig of cilantro and plenty of sauce to mask the fact that there is no zing of fresh flavor every good spring roll should have. I also ordered their fried roll - which did have way more flavor and came with a ponzu sauce. If you are vegan because you are living a healthy lifestyle I wouldn't recommend this place. If you are just trying to eat less meat then this could be a good place to try. They looked to have other food that is hopefully a little tastier then what I ordered.
author: Megan G.

description:
Yummy! When I am in the food court and want something meat-less this is where I pit-stop. 

I have only tried a couple of things but I have had a good experience:

Spicy soup : I can't remember the exact title of this but it's essentially the spicy pho item. This was really good especially on a cold San Francisco day! I wish there was slightly less soy in it (I really don't like eating so much soy, and it could be easily made up for with some more veggies instead). 

Rainbow Salad: This was my vegan crack for months! I love the peanut-y dressing and it's HUGE

Vietnamese Sandwich: This was pretty good too. Tastes better and "cleaner" than a traditional Vietnamese sandwich (and that's coming from an omnivore like me)

Thai tea: Meh...decent but definitely not special.
author: Vanessa T.

description:
Big fat 5 stars from me.  I've eaten here a number of times on different days and different hours and have never been disappointed.  I always get a 2 item combo with brown rice and they HEAP everything on.  I leave stuffed.  Favorites are the sweet potato curry (ohhhh yeah) and the beef n broccoli.  

Great faux meat, good spices, cute restaurant front, solid service.  Definitely one of the top loving huts I've been too.

It's also really cool to see an entirely vegan eatery inside a mall.  UBER-FUCKING-WIN, SAN FRAN.
author: Brian G.

description: The avocado smoothie was so good!!! As well as the Thai tea, pho, & vermicelli bowl. Vegan meats taste really good as well as general flavor of the dishes. Authentic Vietnamese with a vegan twist. Only thing I dislike is that it's in the mall, which encourages me to spend money shopping. Totally worth it though!!!
author: Michon N.
